Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 44-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD) who has been admitted to the ICU. She presented with persistent hypotension and an unknown source of hypotension. The possible causes include cardiogenic shock from decompensated heart failure, sepsis, and less likely pulmonary embolism (PE) as she is not hypoxemic. Pan-cultures have been negative, indicating no signs of infection.

The patient also has a clot at the end of her HD line and a splenic infarct, for which she has been started on heparin. She has a history of retinal hemorrhage, and there is a concern about the risks of ocular hemorrhage with the use of aspirin (ASA), Plavix, and heparin. The plan is to consult an ophthalmologist to weigh in on these risks and consider stopping anticoagulation if the risks are too high.

The patient's volume status needs to be addressed, and she will be placed on fluid restriction. Her diabetes mellitus (DM) requires management, including the initiation of basal long-acting insulin in addition to regular insulin sliding scale.

Regarding access, a new intravenous (IV) line is needed, and a guided percutaneous internal jugular central catheter (PICC) will be placed. The femoral line will be discontinued.

The patient is currently receiving systemic anticoagulation with heparin for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis. She is also receiving stress ulcer prophylaxis with an H2 blocker. There are no ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) concerns at this time.

Code status is full code, and the patient will be transferred to the floor once her condition improves.
